column5: Main crops: sorghum, millets, groundnuts, sunflower, sweet potato, cassava, maize (early maturing and medium term), pigeon pea, hyacinth bean, passion fruit, cotton, sisal, castor, simsim, tea, coffee, Irish potatoes, common beans, grasses and legumes for livestock, grapes, rice, vegetables. Main farming/cropping system: sorghum/bulrush/millet/ Livestock/ maize/ bulrush millet/ cotton/ livestock. Other crops are: oil seeds and rice. Cotton/maize (other crops involved: sweet potato, sorghum and groundnut). Pastoralist/agropastoralist (with shifting cultivation of sorghum). Irrigation: traditional schemes operating with upgraded ones e.g. Lumuma. Major pests: any worms, locusts, rodents, large grain borer. Sources of seed: own saved and from stockists. Fertilizers recommended but used in small quantities.

column4: Covers the majority of the national territory, between 5° and 9° N and the towns of Bouar (Nana Mambéré), Bossembélé (Ombella M'Poko), Bozoum (Ouham Péndé), Bossangoa (Ouham), Kaga Bandoro (Nana Gribizi), Sibut (Kémo), Bambari (Ouaka), Ndélé south, Bria (
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In some areas the density of trees and shrubs limits deep ploughing. Animal traction is used in the savannah and cotton zones for ploughing and transportation. The cropping calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not used in food crop cultivation. The soil is placed on fallow for more than 4 years.

column4: Covers southern towns and along River Oubangui. The towns concerned are: Nola (Sangha Mbaéré), Berberati (Mambéré Kadeï), Mbaïki (Lobaye), Bangui (Ombella M'Poko), Mobaye (Basse-Kotto) and Bangassou (Mbomou).

column5: Subsistence agriculture, non irrigated crops and very little use of fertilizers and pesticides.

column3: Moist Agro-ecology (hot to warm lowlands, tepid to cool moist mid highlands and cold to very cold sub-afroalpine to afroalpine)

column5: Cultivation of both annual and perennial crops is a common practice well as mixed farming. In some part of the zone annual crops especially cereal based crop cultivation is the dominant agricultural practice. Livestock rearing is also practiced as a secondary activity.

column5: Rainfed cropping on forest land (burnt land), in plains and in low lands; high soil occupation; irrigation from starts December for 3 to 4 months only. Short dry season. Rotation rice, groundnut, maize, cassava in small hills and rice, vegetables in low lands; mixed cropping groundnut-maize, maize-cowpea, rice-maize, plantain-food crops and plantain-fruit crops. Control of weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Pwani: Kibaha,Kisarawe, Bagamoyo, Rufiji nad Mafia. Tanga: Handeni, Kilindi, Korongwe, Muheza, Mkinga, Pangani and Tanga City. Morogoro: Morogoro Rural and Mvomero. Mtwara: Masasi, Newala, Tandahimba and Mtwara. Lindi: Lindi, Liwale, Ruangwa and Nachingwe
column5: Main crops: cassava, simsim, finger millet, sorghum, cow pea, pigeon pea, pine apple, sweet potato, soybean, groundnut, passion fruit, finger millet, mango, cashew, cotton, mango, coconut, sisal, jatropha, citrus cloves, rubber, oil palm and sugar cane. Early maturing maize varieties grown in soils with high moisture storing capacity. Crop rotations: maize/beans/maize. Beans -maize/sorghum-cassava. tomato/maize/tomato. Main farming/cropping system: cashew/coconut/cassava; coconut/citrus/maize/cassava/sweet potato. Some shifting cultivation is still practiced. Rice/sugar system found in alluvial river valley (Rufiji, Kilombero river valleys, Morogoro, Mvomero and Pangani. Wet rice and irrigation system at river valleys and alluvial plains. Irrigation: The sugar cane plantations have modern irrigation facilities. Source of seed: mainly from informal system-own saved, gift or exchange or purchased from local market. The system provides about 90% of seeds. Formal system from stockist and provide about 10% of seed source. Fertilizer although recommended are used in small quantities. Major pests: insect pests (army worms, locust), birds (Quellea Quellea), rodents.

column4: Dodoma: Kondoa, dodoama, Bahi, Mpwapwa and Kongwa. Kilimanjaro Rombo, Mwanga, Same, Moshi and Hai. Lindi Liwale, Nachingwea, Kilwa, Lindi and Ruangwa. Tanga:Korongwe, Handeni, Kilindi, Lushoto, Muheza, Mkinga and Pangani. Arusha Monduli and Arumeru. Manya
column5: Carrying capacity: 2 Livestock Unit per sq.km. Main crops: maize, sorghum, rice, cassava, sweet potato, sugarcane, cowpea, pigeon pea, hyacinth bean, citrus, mangoes, passion fruit, pineapple, cashew, coconut, groundnut, soybean, sunflower, tobacco, cotton, tea, coffee, sisal, jatropha, wheat, lablab, castor, simsim, finger millet. Various tropical grasses and legumes for animal fodder. Main farming/cropping system: maize/legumes; maize/legume/horticulture; maize/legume/livestock or legume/sorghum/livestock; banana/coffee/horticulture; banana/coffee/horticulture/livestock. Irrigation: mainly traditional but upscaled in vegetables and rice growing areas. Source of seed: informal and formal. Temperate seeds such as carrot. Cabbages are imported. Major pests: insects: armyworms, locust; birds (Quellea Quellea); rodents.

column4: Lindi: Liwale and Nachingwea.Pwani: Kibaha, Kisarawe and Rufiji. Morogoro:Kilombero, Morogoro, Mvomero, Kilosa and Ulanga. Ruvuma : Mbinga, Songea and Tunduru.
column5: Main crops: coconut, cashew, mangoes, cassava, maize, sorghum, rice, simsim, passion fruit, finger millet, cowpeas, pigeon pea, sweet potato, citrus, sisal, jatropha, castor, groundnut, soybean, sunflower, tobacco, cotton, various tropical grasses and legume for fodder, hyacinth learns. Farming systems: cashew/ coconut/ cassava/ maize/ legume. Sources of seed: own saved stockists and on farm seed production. Major pests: army worms, locusts rodents and large grain borer. Irrigation: several traditional and upgraded schemes functioning. Local varieties: maize, sorghum.

column4: Divisions of Adamawa Region: Djérem, Faro and Déo, Mbéré, Mayo Banyo, Vina
column5: Manual agriculture, with animal traction, monoculture on maize, fertilizer use on maize, mixed cultivation for the other food crops. Mechanized maize cultivation by specialized farmers. Cropping on burnt land.

column4: West Region: Divisions: Mifi, Menoua, Bamboutos, Ndé, Upper-Nkam, Koung-Khi, High-Plateaux. Divisions of the Northwest Region: Mezam, Menchum, Dongang-Mantung, Bui, Momo, Ngoketunjia, Boyo.
column5: Manual agriculture, planting on ridges, animal traction, mixed cropping for food crops. Ploughing in contour lines on hill slopes.

column4: West Region: Divisions: Mifi, Menoua, Bamboutos, Ndé, Upper-Nkam, Koung-Khi, High-Plateaux. Divisions of the Northwest Region: Mezam, Menchum, Dongang-Mantung, Bui, Momo, Ngoketunjia, Boyo.
column5: Manual agriculture, planting on ridges, animal traction, mixed cropping for food crops. Ploughing in contour lines on hill slopes.

column4: Covers the majority of the national territory, between 5° and 9° N and the towns of Bouar (Nana Mambéré), Bossembélé (Ombella M'Poko), Bozoum (Ouham Péndé), Bossangoa (Ouham), Kaga Bandoro (Nana Gribizi), Sibut (Kémo), Bambari (Ouaka), Ndélé south, Bria (
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In some areas the density of trees and shrubs limits deep ploughing. Animal traction is used in the savannah and cotton zones for ploughing and transportation. The cropping calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not used in food crop cultivation. The soil is placed on fallow for more than 4 years.

column4: Covers from West to East the town of Paoua (Ouham Péndé), Batangafo (Ouham), Ndélé (Bamingui Bangoran) and Ouadda (Haute-Kotto)
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In the cotton areas, some farmers use animal traction, but the rest of the system is manual. The cultural calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not applied on food crops. The soil is placed on fallow for a long period for natural regeneration.

column4: Covers southern towns and along River Oubangui. The towns concerned are: Nola (Sangha Mbaéré), Berberati (Mambéré Kadeï), Mbaïki (Lobaye), Bangui (Ombella M'Poko), Mobaye (Basse-Kotto) and Bangassou (Mbomou).
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. The high density of trees limits deep ploughing.

column4: Sanannah, Denguélé, and North of Worodougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: cashew-nut, cotton, mango. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is cotton/maize-based. Good knowledge on the use of animal traction, pesticides and fertilizers.

column5: Rainfed cropping on forest land (burnt land), in plains and in low lands; high soil occupation; irrigation from starts December for 3 to 4 months only. Short dry season. Control of weeds, pests and diseases.

column5: Rainfed cropping in plains, lowlands and forest lands (burnt land). Mixture of crops of the Sudan and the Guinea forest zones. Association maize-cowpea, rice-maize and plantain-food crops. Control of animal digression, pests and diseases.

column4: Between the lowlands and the mountains of seven districts (Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing) and cover 15% of the country (545,500 ha). The plateaus are interrupted by mountain spurs and river valleys.
column5: Summer crops: maize, sorghum, beans, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Earlier planting than lowlands. Mixed farming (crops and livestock). Intensive and commercial farming follows that of lowlands. Gravity fed and sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is a small strip of land of the seven districts, Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing comprising 12% of the land area on the western part of country boarding the eastern Free State Province of the Republic of South Af
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is an extension of the lowlands in the south eastern part of the country, Quthing to Qachas Nek along the Senqu River and its tributary valleys covering 8% of the land area and even parts of Thaba-Tseka have similar conditions.
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation. Sorghum thrives well in this zone due to its better drought tolerance than maize.

column4: Between the lowlands and the mountains of seven districts (Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing) and cover 15% of the country (545,500 ha). The plateaus are interrupted by mountain spurs and river valleys.

column4: Hight lands of Zambézia, Niassa, Angonia, Maravia and Maniça.

column4: Comprises Fatick, Kaolack and Diourbel regions, Mbour Division and an important part of Thiès, Tivaouane, Kébémer and Louga Divisions.
column5: As noted from its name, this zone is dominated by groundnut cultivation, in alternation with rainfed millet (les than 1% of the land is irrigated). Agricultural practices are characterized by the disappearance of fallows due to the high human pressure on land and the absence of policy to maintain soil fertility. This explains the multiple factors of land deterioration, amplified by extensive livestock activities that consume the few plants found and protected areas dominated by species of Combretaceae and Mimosaceae (mostly Faidherbia albida).

column5: Manual agriculture, with animal traction, monoculture is generally practiced; fertilizer and chemical pest control used on cotton and irrigated rice. Rice irrigation is practiced in Lagdo and in SEMRY company.

column4: Divisions of Adamawa Region: Djérem, Faro and Déo, Mbéré, Mayo Banyo, Vina
column5: Manual agriculture, with animal traction, monoculture on maize, fertilizer use on maize, mixed cultivation for the other food crops. Mechanized maize cultivation by specialized farmers. Cropping on burnt land.

column4: Sanannah, Denguélé, and North of Worodougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: cashew-nut, cotton, mango. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is cotton/maize-based. Good knowledge on the use of animal traction, pesticides and fertilizers.

column4: Bandaman valley, Lakes, North of N'Zi Comoé, Zanzan, and South of Worogougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam, cassava. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: banana, plantain, cocoa, cashew-nut, cotton. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is yam-based.

column4: Fromager, Marahoué, Agnéby; Mid-Comoé, South of N'Zi Comoé, Mid-Cavally and Bafing Regions
column5: Oil crops: oil palm, coconut. Cereals: Maize. Root and tubers: yam, cassava. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: banana, plantain, cocoa, coffee, rubber. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is essentially upland rice and cassava or yam in the east.

column4: Sanannah, Denguélé, and North of Worodougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: cashew-nut, cotton, mango. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is cotton/maize-based. Good knowledge on the use of animal traction, pesticides and fertilizers.

column4: Bandaman valley, Lakes, North of N'Zi Comoé, Zanzan, and South of Worogougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam, cassava. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: banana, plantain, cocoa, cashew-nut, cotton. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is yam-based.

column3: Near by Delta region old reclaimed soils "NDRORL"
column4: South Tahrir (Menofia), North and ElBostan Tahrir (Behiara), Gable Asfer (Kalubia),  Abu Kbir (Sharqiea), Kassasein and Abu sultan (Ismaeilia)
column5: Salty to sandy soil drip or furrow irrigation method by water from Nile connected channels using simple pumps or high pressure pumps

column3: Humid agro-ecology (hot to warm lowlands, tepid to cool mid highlands and cold to very cold humid sub-afroalpine to afroalpine)
column4: Tepi, Jinka, Konso, Derashe, Masha and Sidama zone in the Southern Nations and Nationalities People Regional state, Jima zone, Arsi zone (Ticho, Adelle, Mount Chilalo and Kaka), Bale zone (Dinsho and the surrounding area) in Oromiya National Regional Stat
column5: Cereal based, enset based and shifting cultivation are the common agricultural practices along with animal rearing.

column3: Semi-Arid Agro-ecology (Hot to warm lowlands and tepid to cool mid highlands)
column4: Situated in Humera area of western Tigray, North east of Alem Tena and around bulbula in Central part of Oromiya, Metema and Abderafi in North Gonder, and Hamerbako area in the Tigray, Amhara and Southern Nations and Nationalities People Regional States.
column5: Nomadic pastoralism and agro-pastoralism is the major agricultural practice in part of the semi-arid area and in the other part is mechanized and traditional crop cultivation is a common agricultural practice.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column4: Kalinko, Selouma, Lansanya, Gnagnakaly, Datifèrè, M'bonè (Dinguiraye); Dogomè, Alpha Moussaya, Kankama, Dialakoro, Bissikirima, Banko, Konidou, N'dèma, Kindoyé (Dabola); Marela, Snadeniya, Passaya, Heremakono, Niala, Tiro, Sangoya, Bagnan, Kobikoro, Bèndo
column5: Rainfed cropping in plains and on burnt land. Irrigation of the crops at off-season from October; rotation rice/cotton/cassava/fonio or cotton/groundnut/maize in hills; rice/vegetables in plains. Control of animal damage, weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Konkouré, Wouré Kaba, Soya, Boulywel, Tolo, Timbo, Saramoussaya, Poredaka, Bouriya, Gongorè, Gnagara, Kegneko (Mamou); Koba, Mity, Ditinn, Boyé, Kanka Labé, Kebaly (Dalaba); Brouwal Tapè, Bantignèl, Massi, Sangaréah, Leymirou, Dongöl Touma, Ningué Landè,
column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Rainfed cultivation on burnt land is practiced after a short fallow. Intensive cultivation of vegetables and potato in pluvial and under irrigation in dry season. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column4: Mambia, Molota, Friguiagbé, Damakania, Madina-Oula, Bangouya, Sougueta, Kolenté, Samaya (Kindia); Kollet, Sogolon, Thionthian, Gougoudjè, Daramaganki, Konsotamy, Missira, Koba, Santou, Tarihoye, Sarekaly, Brouwal (Telimelé); Tormelin, Baguinè et Banguingn
column5: Rainfed crops with slash and burn type of agriculture (dominant in the north), in plain and lowland. Irrigation starting from late November for non seasonal crops, especially for vegetable crops (dominant in the south). Crops rotation of rice/groundnut/cassava and fonio; rice/vegetable - maize/groundnut. Association of rice-sorghum and groundnut-maize. Fight against weeds, rodents, birds and treatment against diseases and insects.

column4: Albadaria, Sangardo, Fèmèssadou, Yombiro, Yèndèmillimou, Kondiadou, Bardou, Bèndou, Bandama, Firawa, Manfara, Gbangbadou (Kissidougou); Karala, Diassodou, Samana, Fouala, Sinko, Koumandou, Gbèssoba, Gbakedou, Diaraguerela, Gnonsamoridou, Boola (Beyla); Si
column5: Rainfed cropping in plains, lowlands and forest lands (burnt land). Mixture of crops of the Sudan and the Guinea forest zones. Irrigation at off-seasons from December (West preforest zone) and November (preforest zone). Rotation rice-groundnut-cassava in small hill and rice-vegetables-maize in low lands. Association maize-cowpea, rice-maize and plantain-food crops. Control of animal digression, pests and diseases.

column4: Kassadou, Kpaladou, Tèmèssadou, Kondou, Nongowa, Fangamadou, Wèndèkènèma, Tékoulo, Guèdèmbou (Guekedou); Bofossou, Vatanga, Binikala, Balizia, Daro, Vourémeï, Sérédou, Sengbédou, Kouankan, N'zebela, Fassakoni, Koyama (Macenta); Koulé, Kpalé, Koropara, Kob
column5: Rainfed cropping on forest land (burnt land), in plains and in low lands; high soil occupation; irrigation from starts December for 3 to 4 months only. Short dry season. Rotation rice, groundnut, maize, cassava in small hills and rice, vegetables in low lands; mixed cropping groundnut-maize, maize-cowpea, rice-maize, plantain-food crops and plantain-fruit crops. Control of weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Menabe Region: (districts of Miandrivazo, Belo-Tsiribihina, Mahabo, Morondava, Manja).
column5: Rice, cotton (in baiboho), groundnut, maize, cassava, cape pea, bean, sugar cane, legumes. Cultivation of subsidence crops. Need hydraulic structures. Protection of banks by reforestation.

column4: Sava Region: (district of Andapa); Sofia Region: (districts of Bealanana, Mandritsara, Befandriana Avaratra).
column5: Coffee, rice, cassava.

column3: High West Atlas, Haouz and Haha Zone
column4: Provinces of Safi, Essaouira, and Marrakech
column5: All the cultivated crops of Morocco, except the date palm. The Haouz plain is partly irrigated.

column4: Tillabéri Region: South Say; Division; Dosso Region: Gaya Division; Maradi Region: South Madarounfa; Division; Zinder Region: South Matamèye and Magaria Divisions.
column5: Mainly rainfed cropping; suitable zone for cereals and legumes and roots and tubers (cassava, sweet potato).

column4: Tillabéri Region: South Say; Division; Dosso Region: Gaya Division; Maradi Region: South Madarounfa; Division; Zinder Region: South Matamèye and Magaria Divisions.
column5: Mainly rainfed cropping; suitable zone for cereals and legumes and roots and tubers (cassava, sweet potato).

column4: South Central Somalia
column5: Rainfed sorghum, maize and cowpeas

column4: Galgudud, Hiraan and Middle Shabelle regions of South Central Somalia
column5: Rainfed sorghum, maize, cowpea, sesame, and water melon

column4: South Central Somalia
column5: Rainfed and irrigated maize, sorghum, sesame, cowpeas, rice, variety of vegetables, sweetpotato, fruits and cash crops

column4: Bizerte, Béja, Jendouba and the North part of Cape Bon
column5: Cereal cropping, extensive livestock and arboriculture.

column4: Lindi: Liwale and Nachingwea.Pwani: Kibaha, Kisarawe and Rufiji. Morogoro:Kilombero, Morogoro, Mvomero, Kilosa and Ulanga. Ruvuma : Mbinga, Songea and Tunduru.
column5: Main crops: coconut, cashew, mangoes, cassava, maize, sorghum, rice, simsim, passion fruit, finger millet, cowpeas, pigeon pea, sweet potato, citrus, sisal, jatropha, castor, groundnut, soybean, sunflower, tobacco, cotton, various tropical grasses and legume for fodder, hyacinth learns. Farming systems: cashew/ coconut/ cassava/ maize/ legume. Sources of seed: own saved stockists and on farm seed production. Major pests: army worms, locusts rodents and large grain borer. Irrigation: several traditional and upgraded schemes functioning. Local varieties: maize, sorghum.

column4: Municipalities:  Karimama,  Malanville, North Kandi Municipality
column5: Main crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, soybean, groundnut, okra, rice, potato, tomato, pepper, onion. Rice, potato, tomato. onion is irrigated

column5: Pluvial agriculture (millet, maize, sorghum, cowpeas, tubers), cash crops (cotton) and irrigated crops (rice, vegetable crops) as well as sedentary livestock comprised mainly of small ruminants and bovines.
column11: Variety: K.E.J. Barka, extra early for traditional agriculture

column4: The zone covers the provinces of Gourman, Gnagnan, Tapoa, Kompienga and Komandjari.
column5: Extensive rainfed agriculture (millet, maize, sorghum, groundnut, cowpea, cotton...) and irrigated agriculture (rice, vegetables) and extensive livestock rearing (bovine, small ruminant and poultry).
column11: Variety: K.E.J. Barka, extra early for traditional agriculture

column11: Variety: K.E.J. Barka, extra early for traditional agriculture

column4: It is represented by north Birao (Vakaga) station, Ndélé (Bamingui) and its environs
column5: The cropping system is manual and entirely dependent on rainfall. Ploughing is superficial, with a hoe. Crops are grown within floodable areas.

column4: Covers from West to East the town of Paoua (Ouham Péndé), Batangafo (Ouham), Ndélé (Bamingui Bangoran) and Ouadda (Haute-Kotto)
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In the cotton areas, some farmers use animal traction, but the rest of the system is manual. The cultural calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not applied on food crops. The soil is placed on fallow for a long period for natural regeneration.

column4: It is represented by north Birao (Vakaga) station, Ndélé (Bamingui) and its environs

column4: Covers the majority of the national territory, between 5° and 9° N and the towns of Bouar (Nana Mambéré), Bossembélé (Ombella M'Poko), Bozoum (Ouham Péndé), Bossangoa (Ouham), Kaga Bandoro (Nana Gribizi), Sibut (Kémo), Bambari (Ouaka), Ndélé south, Bria (
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In some areas the density of trees and shrubs limits deep ploughing. Animal traction is used in the savannah and cotton zones for ploughing and transportation. The cropping calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not used in food crop cultivation. The soil is placed on fallow for more than 4 years.

column4: Covers southern towns and along River Oubangui. The towns concerned are: Nola (Sangha Mbaéré), Berberati (Mambéré Kadeï), Mbaïki (Lobaye), Bangui (Ombella M'Poko), Mobaye (Basse-Kotto) and Bangassou (Mbomou).
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. The high density of trees limits deep ploughing.

column4: North wollo and North Showa in the Amhara, Alamata and Sheket in the Tigray, Asebot in Afar, Bale, Fike, West Harargie and Afdem in Oromiya National Regional States
column5: The zone has two farming systems, cereal based and enset based agriculture, along with livestock rearing. Double dependable growing period (bulg or first season and meher or second season) and one dry season also exist.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column3: Oyem, Bitam, Minvoul, Mitzic and Médouneu
column4: Woleu Ntem province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: Population density is not very high in the Woleu N'tem zone, and there is no problem with land availability. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 8 to 12 years. As in the Estuary province, pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column5: Rainfed cropping in plains and on burnt land. Irrigation of the crops at off-season from October; rotation rice/cotton/cassava/fonio or cotton/groundnut/maize in hills; rice/vegetables in plains. Control of animal damage, weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Cisséla, Sanguiana, Douako, Banfèlè, Kiniero, Baro, Babila, Koumana, Balato, Dougoura (Kouroussa); Gbérédou baranama, Balandou, Missamana, Sabadou baranama, Tintioulén, Moribaya, Tokounou, Mamourodou, Koumban (Kankan); Norassoba, Niandankoro, Kiniébakoura
column5: Rainfed cropping in the plains, on burnt land and low lands (use of short cycle varieties in the North at Niagassola), Irrigation of crops from end of October to beginning of November. Rotations cotton-maize-groundnut, rice-yam-cotton, rice-cassava in small hills and rice-vegetables in level and low lands, Associations groundnut-millet, groundnut-sorghum, maize-groundnut. Control of iron toxicity, weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Kakoni, Kounsitel, Wendou M'Borou, Koubia, Foulamori, Touba, Malanta (Gaoual); Kamabi, Sareboyido, Sambaïlo, Guingan, Teremessè, Youkounkoun (Koundara).
column5: Short rainy season requires the use of short-season varieties. Rainfed rice in pure culture in the vast northern plains. Beginning of the irrigation period in late october. Crops rotation of rice-arachide/cassava/fonio and rice/vegetable crops. Association of maize-taro-maize-potato; rice-sorghum; fight against weeds and rodents, treatment against insects and diseases.

column5: Rainfed cultures in plains, lowland and slash and burn agriculture. Irrigation of non seasonal crops, rotations of rice/vegetable crops/maize; rice/groundnut/cassava. Fight against crabs and other predators, saline rising in mangrove plain. Fight against weeds, treatment against insects and diseases.

column4: Comprises the south of 4 wilayas (Regions): Trarza (the Moughataa of Boghé, Bababé and M'Bagne),  Gorgol (the Moughataa of Kaédi and Maghama),  Guidimakha (the Moughataa of Sélibaby)
column5: Agriculture: dominant. Rainfed and subsidence crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, watermelon, etc). Irrigated crops: rice, maize, sorghum, vegetables, fruit trees. Cultural techniques: dominated by manual practices. Riziculture: manual in Upper River (Brakna, Gorgol, Guidimakha), semi mechanized in lower River (Trarza for land preparation and harvesting). Use of herbicides: frequent.

column4: Comprises 3 wilayas (Regions): Assaba, 2 Hodhs without Moughataa (Divisions), Ould Yengé (Guidimakha), Mbout and Monguel (Gorgol), Aleg and Magta-Lahjar (Brakna), Mederdra and R'Kiz (Trarza).
column5: Rainfed crops and crops grown under dam (sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea). Mixed cropping is common and fertilizer use is rare. Use of animal traction: rare. Use of manure: frequent. column5: Oasis crops; gardening, date palm, citrus. Water used for irrigation is drawn manually with ropes from wells or with "Chadouf" and/or "Dalou" drawn by animals. Rainfed crops: cereals, legumes.

column5: Rainfed crops: cereals (millet, sorghum, rice) legumes (cowpea), off-season crops: vegetables and fruit trees.

column4: Diffa Region: South Diffa and South Maïné Soroa Divisions; Zinder Region: Matamèye, Magaria, South Gouré and Mirriah Centre and South Divisions. Maradi Region: Tessaoua, Aguié, Guidan Roumdji, Madarounfa, South Mayahi, Sud Dakoro; Divisions; Tahoua Region
column5: Rainfed crops: cereals (millet, sorghum, rice) legumes (cowpea), off-season crops: vegetables and fruit trees.

column4: Comprises the Region of Dakar, and the Atlantic coast of the Regions of Thiès, Louga and Saint-Louis.
column5: About 80% of the horticultural production of the country is provided by this zone, only about 7% of the land is irrigated. There is intensive rearing (bovine and poultry). However, pressure on water resources and land combined with low rainfall leads to progressive land salinity and sandiness following vegetation degradation and progressive dune threats.

column4: Comprises far north parts of the Dagana, Podor, Matam and Bakel administrative Divisions.
column5: Rice cultivation, irrigated vegetable production and subsidence cropping are practiced in the Walo (zone closed to water sources). The main subsidence crops are sorghum and maize that are grown on flood lands of the Walo, after the withdrawal of river waters following the annual rise in the water level occurring in rainy season. Rainfed crops such as millet, groundnut, tropical-type vegetables, etc. are cultivated Diéri. There is artisan fishing in rivers, lake Guiers and their different branching as well as the extensive livestock in Diéri. The development of rice cultivation and intensive deforestation have led to problems of chemical degradation of waters, wind and water erosion as well as salinization and alkalinization of soils in this zone.

column4: Most of Sudan, mainly in Kordofan, Darfur, White Nile & Blue Nile. North parts of Gadarif, Southern parts of Kassala & Kordofan containing Qash, Abu Habbil and Tokar Deltas. Southern parts of Kordofan, Southern parts of Gadarif & Southern parts of Souther
column5: Traditional rainfed farming subsistence production is practised, mainly sorghum, millet and limited areas under horticultural crops. Traditional rainfed is practised mainly sorghum and sesame. Irrigated Truck-Production is mainly practised in which cotton, groundnut and wheat is cultivated. Mainly Truck-Production is practised for sorghum, it is semi-mechanized, and illicit wood cut is practised affecting badly the forests.

column4: Parts of Northern, Southern & Western Darfur
column5: Due to its height this zone is characterized by its different climates and obviously different crops including tobacco and forest wealth.

column5: Direct planting, transplanting and propagate vegetatively some fruit crops, broadcasting and drilling field crops. Wheat and Faba been cultivated by the floods in Hud es-Sileim. column5: Suitable for irrigation in the bordering side of the East with weak slopes dominated by several industrial sugar cane plantations. North regions difficult to irrigate because of small undulating hills with average slopes. Mixed farming cropping especially in the North, monoculture in the East and bovine rearing because of natural pastures. Intensive exploitation of marsh lands in the northern depressions

column3: Low-Medium Altitude Semi-Arid and Sub-Humid Zones
column4: Santiago: Praia (Rªs de Cidade Velha, S. Martinho Grande e Pequeno); S. Domingos (Rª de Baía, Rª de Acahada Baleia, Monte Negro, Lagoa); Santa Cruz (Rª Seca, Rª da Picos, Rª de Santa Cruz); Santa Catarina (Rª Flamengos, Rª do Charco, Rª da Barca, Rª Boa E
column5: Irrigated zone especially in the valleys and on terrace slopes. Irrigation from water sources, wells and borings. In the recent years, fruit production has been market-driven with modernization of the irrigation system with drippers.

column4: S. Nicolau (Fajã, Rª das Pratas-Fragata, Rª Brava, Caleijão, Queimadas, Juncalinho, Água das Patas)S. Antão: Porto Novo (Rª da Cruz, Alto Mira, Martiene, Lagedos, Rª Fria, Rª dos Bodes, Casa de Meio) - Sud et Ouest; Fogo: S. Filipe (Achada Malva, Patim, F
column5: Rainfed cultivation in maize and common beans. Pluvial land (35 ha) converted to irrigated areas (Faja Galery). Irrigated crops on wind-protected valleys with micro-climate that is favourable for sugar cane and fruit production. Fruits (mango) on the sides of the valleys with complementary irrigation. High water deficit in some zones according to season. Gravitational irrigation with water from streams and wells. Moderate micro-climate in hot humid season (July - Oct.) conducive for fruit and vegetable production (potato, cabbage, sweetpotato, citrus and mango). Little or no pests with the exception of millipedes. Insufficient rainfall. Irrigation of small farms with water bored more than 100 m deep on slopes. Water pumping from the sea level with several intermediate stations. Potential for roots and tuber production, pineapple, pawpaw and horticultural crops with micro-irrigation. Very high price of water.

column5: Irrigated zone especially in the valleys and on terrace slopes. Irrigation from water sources, wells and borings. In the recent years, fruit production has been market-driven with modernization of the irrigation system with drippers.

column4: São Vicente (Monte Verde); S. Nicolau (Monte Gordo, Fajã de Riba); S. Antão (Cova, Corda, Covão, Fundão, Pintão, Lombo Branco, Figueiral, Pico da Cruz, Santa Isabel,..) - Centre; Fogo: Mosteiros (Monte Velha, Rª do Iheu, Atalaia Campanas, Galinheiro) - No
column5: Rainfed cultivation of some food crops (maize, common beans, roots and tubers, groundnuts and some vegetables (2 cropping season/year). In the altitude there is cultivation of maize/common beans, sweetpotato, and temperate fruits (apple, peach, grape, quince). Rainfed cultivation at the altitude of 600-700 m crops such as maize/common beans, tubers, coffee. Rainfed cultivation of maize, common beans, cucurbits, roots and tubers predominate. The mixed system (pluvial/irrigated is very developed in this zone. There are pre-rainfed crops such as cabbage, potato, lettuce, etc) and some experience with harvesting surface  waters and clouds (S. malagueta).

column4: Divisions of the Littoral Region: Wouri, Nkam, Sanaga Maritime, Mungo. Divisions of the Southwest Region: Manyu, Ndian, Fako, Meme, Lebialem, Kupe-Manenguba.
column5: Manual agriculture, mixed cropping for the food crops. Industrial plantations of rubber, tea, banana and oil palms. Flat ploughing.

column4: Divisions of the Centre Region: Mfoundi, Nyong and Kéllé, Upper Sanaga, Lékié, Nyon and So'o, Mefou and Afamba, Mbam and Inoubou, Mbam and Kim, Mefou and Akono. Divisions of the South Region: Dja and Lobo, Ocean, Ntem Ntem, Mvilla. Divisions of the East R
column5: Manual agriculture, and with animal traction, mixed cropping for food crops. Flat manual plough.

column4: West Region: Divisions: Mifi, Menoua, Bamboutos, Ndé, Upper-Nkam, Koung-Khi, High-Plateaux. Divisions of the Northwest Region: Mezam, Menchum, Dongang-Mantung, Bui, Momo, Ngoketunjia, Boyo.
column5: Manual agriculture, planting on ridges, animal traction, mixed cropping for food crops. Ploughing in contour lines on hill slopes.

column4: West Region: Divisions: Mifi, Menoua, Bamboutos, Ndé, Upper-Nkam, Koung-Khi, High-Plateaux. Divisions of the Northwest Region: Mezam, Menchum, Dongang-Mantung, Bui, Momo, Ngoketunjia, Boyo.
column5: Manual agriculture, planting on ridges, animal traction, mixed cropping for food crops. Ploughing in contour lines on hill slopes.

column4: Sanannah, Denguélé, and North of Worodougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: cashew-nut, cotton, mango. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is cotton/maize-based. Good knowledge on the use of animal traction, pesticides and fertilizers.

column4: Bandaman valley, Lakes, North of N'Zi Comoé, Zanzan, and South of Worogougou Regions
column5: Cereals: maize, millet, sorghum. Roots and tubers: yam, cassava. Vegetables and legume crops: all types. Other crops: banana, plantain, cocoa, cashew-nut, cotton. Food crops are generally associated together or with perennial crops in the first years. Cropping system is yam-based.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column4: Nyanza province (Kisii), Western province (Mt Elgon), Eastern province (Meru), Central province (Kiambu, Nyeri), Rift valley province (Nandi, Kericho,T/Nzoia, W/pokot, Keiyo/Markwet, Baringo,Nakuru, Narok)
column5: Wheat, maize and pyrethrum farming.

column4: Diana Region (districts of Antsiranana I et II, Ambilobe, Ambanja, Nosy Be); Region Sava (districts of  Vohémar, Antalaha, Sambava); Analanjirofo Region (district of Maroantsetra).
column5: Cocoa, coffee, pepper, sugarcane, vanilla, oil palm, coconut, groundnut, maize, cassava, vegetable crops, potato. Needs anti-erosive structures on steep slopes and drainage of valleys.

column4: Betsiboka Region: (districts of Tsaratanana, Maevatanana, Kandreho); Analamanga Region: (district of Ankazobe); Bongolava Region: (districts of Tsiroanomandidy, Fenoarivo Be); Itasy Region: (districts of Miarinarivo, Soavinandriana); Vakinankaratra Region
column5: Rice, groundnut, maize, cassava, soybean, onion, tomato, fruit trees. Zones highly exposed to erosion due to frequent bush fires. Swamps and lowlands need necessary hydraulic structures (especially drainage).

column4: Analamanga Region: (districts of Anjozorobe, Antananarivo Atsimondrano, Antananarivo Avaradrano, Antananarivo Renivohitra, Ambohidratrimo, Manjakandriana, Andramasina); Itasy Region: (district of Arivonimamo); Vakinankaratra Region: (districts of Ambatola
column5: Arabica coffee, tea, wheat, rice, potato, maize, cassava, fruit trees, vegetable crops, Drainage problems in valleys.

column4: Diana Region (districts of Antsiranana I et II, Ambilobe, Ambanja, Nosy Be); Region Sava (districts of  Vohémar, Antalaha, Sambava); Analanjirofo Region (district of Maroantsetra).
column5: Cocoa, coffee, pepper, sugarcane, vanilla, oil palm, coconut, groundnut, maize, cassava, vegetable crops, potato. Needs anti-erosive structures on steep slopes and drainage of valleys.

column4: Comprises the  wilayas (Regions) of Tiris Zemmour, Adrar, Inchiri and Tagant, the Moughataa of Boumdeïd (Assaba), Tamchakett (Hodh El Gharbi) and Oulata (Hodh Echarghui)
column5: Oasis-type agriculture: date palm dominated with sub stages of fruit trees, cereals (wheat, oat), vegetables (carrot, tomato, cabbage and forage (alfalfa). Sometimes recessional crops are found around oases and behind dams on limono sandy soils.

column4: Comprises the south of 4 wilayas (Regions): Trarza (the Moughataa of Boghé, Bababé and M'Bagne),  Gorgol (the Moughataa of Kaédi and Maghama),  Guidimakha (the Moughataa of Sélibaby)
column5: Agriculture: dominant. Rainfed and subsidence crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, watermelon, etc). Irrigated crops: rice, maize, sorghum, vegetables, fruit trees. Cultural techniques: dominated by manual practices. Riziculture: manual in Upper River (Brakna, Gorgol, Guidimakha), semi mechanized in lower River (Trarza for land preparation and harvesting). Use of herbicides: frequent.

column4: Comprises 3 wilayas (Regions): Assaba, 2 Hodhs without Moughataa (Divisions), Ould Yengé (Guidimakha), Mbout and Monguel (Gorgol), Aleg and Magta-Lahjar (Brakna), Mederdra and R'Kiz (Trarza).
column5: Rainfed crops and crops grown under dam (sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea). Mixed cropping is common and fertilizer use is rare. Use of animal traction: rare. Use of manure: frequent. Cultural operations: manual. Crop protection: seed treatments with fungicides. Use of improved varieties: rare. Vegetable cropping: developed by women cooperatives.

column4: Comprises the  wilayas (Regions) of Tiris Zemmour, Adrar, Inchiri and Tagant, the Moughataa of Boumdeïd (Assaba), Tamchakett (Hodh El Gharbi) and Oulata (Hodh Echarghui)
column5: Oasis-type agriculture: date palm dominated with sub stages of fruit trees, cereals (wheat, oat), vegetables (carrot, tomato, cabbage and forage (alfalfa). Sometimes recessional crops are found around oases and behind dams on limono sandy soils.

column4: Diffa Region: South Diffa and South Maïné Soroa Divisions; Zinder Region: Matamèye, Magaria, South Gouré and Mirriah Centre and South Divisions. Maradi Region: Tessaoua, Aguié, Guidan Roumdji, Madarounfa, South Mayahi, Sud Dakoro; Divisions; Tahoua Region
column5: Rainfed crops: cereals (millet, sorghum, rice) legumes (cowpea), off-season crops: vegetables and fruit trees.

column4: Northern State, Rive Nile State, northern parts of North Darfur State & western parts of Red Sea State. In addition to Gadarif, Blue Nile, Upper Nile, White Nile, Sinnar & Southern Kordofan States
column5: Direct planting, transplanting and propagate vegetatively some fruit crops, broadcasting and drilling field crops. Wheat and Faba been cultivated by the floods in Hud es-Sileim. Datepalm fruit planed in the Nile banks. Commercial rainfed semi-mechanized farming production is practised, mainly sorghum plantation followed by sesame, groundnut and hibiscus (Karkade)

column4: Parts of Northern, Southern & Western Darfur
column5: Due to its height this zone is characterized by its different climates and obviously different crops including tobacco and forest wealth.

column4: Most of Sudan, mainly in Kordofan, Darfur, White Nile & Blue Nile. North parts of Gadarif, Southern parts of Kassala & Kordofan containing Qash, Abu Habbil and Tokar Deltas. Southern parts of Kordofan, Southern parts of Gadarif & Southern parts of Souther
column5: Traditional rainfed farming subsistence production is practised, mainly sorghum, millet and limited areas under horticultural crops. Traditional rainfed is practised mainly sorghum and sesame. Irrigated Truck-Production is mainly practised in which cotton, groundnut and wheat is cultivated. Mainly Truck-Production is practised for sorghum, it is semi-mechanized, and illicit wood cut is practised affecting badly the forests.

column4: Most of Sudan, mainly in Kordofan, Darfur, White Nile & Blue Nile. North parts of Gadarif, Southern parts of Kassala & Kordofan containing Qash, Abu Habbil and Tokar Deltas. Southern parts of Kordofan, Southern parts of Gadarif & Southern parts of Souther
column5: Traditional rainfed farming subsistence production is practised, mainly sorghum, millet and limited areas under horticultural crops. column3: Northeast and Cape Bon (mild winter semi arid)
column4: Grand Tunis and the South part of Cape Bon
column5: The slopes are stiff and irregular; soils are poor and agricultural potential is low. Big crops, livestock and arboriculture.

column4: Kairouan, Sousse, Monastir, Mahdia and Sfax
column5: Dry agriculture is locally possible with a good surface water management. Arboriculture, livestock and vegetables.

column4: Districts of Kitgum, Pader, Lira, Dokolo, Amolatar, Apac, Oyam, Gulu and Amuru
column5: Rainfed crop cultivation, consisting of sorghum, millet, cassava, sesame and pulses. Some rearing of cattle and small ruminants.

column4: Districts of Kamuli, Kaliro, Iganga, Jinja, Mayuge, Kayunga and Bugiri
column5: Mostly rainfed crop cultivation of cereals, oil seeds and pulses. Paddy rice grown in drained swamps.

column4: Districts of Kaberamaido, Katakwi, Amuria, Soroti, Kumi, Bukedea, Pallisa, Budaka, Butaleja, Tororo and Busia
column5: Rainfed crop agriculture, consisting of cereals, oil crops and pulses with moderate livestock rearing. Paddy rice grown in drained swamps

column5: Mostly rainfed crop cultivation of cereals, oil seeds and pulses. Paddy rice grown in drained swamps.

column5: Irrigated zone especially in the valleys and on terrace slopes. Irrigation from water sources, wells and borings. In the recent years, fruit production has been market-driven with modernization of the irrigation system with drippers.

column4: Sal (Terra Boa); Boa Vista (Rª de Sta Isabel, Bofareira, Estância de Baixo, João Galego, Cabeça dos Tarafes, Fundo Figueira, Rabil); Maio (Laje Branca- Cascabulho, Figueira Horta- Rª Chico Vaz, Rª Lagoa). São Vicente (Rª  Vinha, Rª Madeiral, Rª Calhau, Rª
column5: Rainfed agriculture is marginal. Horticultural production hydroponic greenhouse is in full expansion.Rainfed cultivation of maize, common beans, date palms, watermelon, coconut, and melon. Horticultural production on a small scale.Rainfed maize, common beans. Water distribution not even.Potential for irrigated cultivation of onions and roots and tubers.The pluvial agriculture is limited. Irrigation from wells situated in valleys. Pumping with wind energy from shallow well. Very high salinity especially at the end of season (May - July). The majority of horticultural crops (lettuce, beetroot, coriander, cabbage,..) are cultivated with the dripper irrigation. Very strong winds. Use of wind breaks and cultivation in insect-proof greenhouses (tomato, lettuce, cabbage,..).

column4: S. Nicolau (Fajã, Rª das Pratas-Fragata, Rª Brava, Caleijão, Queimadas, Juncalinho, Água das Patas)S. Antão: Porto Novo (Rª da Cruz, Alto Mira, Martiene, Lagedos, Rª Fria, Rª dos Bodes, Casa de Meio) - Sud et Ouest; Fogo: S. Filipe (Achada Malva, Patim, F
column5: Rainfed cultivation in maize and common beans. Pluvial land (35 ha) converted to irrigated areas (Faja Galery). Irrigated crops on wind-protected valleys with micro-climate that is favourable for sugar cane and fruit production. Fruits (mango) on the sides of the valleys with complementary irrigation. High water deficit in some zones according to season. Gravitational irrigation with water from streams and wells. Moderate micro-climate in hot humid season (July - Oct.) conducive for fruit and vegetable production (potato, cabbage, sweetpotato, citrus and mango). Little or no pests with the exception of millipedes. Insufficient rainfall. Irrigation of small farms with water bored more than 100 m deep on slopes. Water pumping from the sea level with several intermediate stations. Potential for roots and tuber production, pineapple, pawpaw and horticultural crops with micro-irrigation. Very high price of water.

column4: Covers the majority of the national territory, between 5° and 9° N and the towns of Bouar (Nana Mambéré), Bossembélé (Ombella M'Poko), Bozoum (Ouham Péndé), Bossangoa (Ouham), Kaga Bandoro (Nana Gribizi), Sibut (Kémo), Bambari (Ouaka), Ndélé south, Bria (
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In some areas the density of trees and shrubs limits deep ploughing. Animal traction is used in the savannah and cotton zones for ploughing and transportation. The cropping calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not used in food crop cultivation. The soil is placed on fallow for more than 4 years.

column4: It is represented by north Birao (Vakaga) station, Ndélé (Bamingui) and its environs
column5: The cropping system is manual and entirely dependent on rainfall. Ploughing is superficial, with a hoe. Crops are grown within floodable areas.

column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In the cotton areas, some farmers use animal traction, but the rest of the system is manual. The cultural calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not applied on food crops. The soil is placed on fallow for a long period for natural regeneration.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column5: Rainfed cultures in plains, lowland and slash and burn agriculture. Irrigation of non seasonal crops, rotations of rice/vegetable crops/maize; rice/groundnut/cassava. Fight against crabs and other predators, saline rising in mangrove plain. Fight against weeds, treatment against insects and diseases.

column4: Albadaria, Sangardo, Fèmèssadou, Yombiro, Yèndèmillimou, Kondiadou, Bardou, Bèndou, Bandama, Firawa, Manfara, Gbangbadou (Kissidougou); Karala, Diassodou, Samana, Fouala, Sinko, Koumandou, Gbèssoba, Gbakedou, Diaraguerela, Gnonsamoridou, Boola (Beyla); Si
column5: Rainfed cropping in plains, lowlands and forest lands (burnt land). Mixture of crops of the Sudan and the Guinea forest zones. Irrigation at off-seasons from December (West preforest zone) and November (preforest zone). Rotation rice-groundnut-cassava in small hill and rice-vegetables-maize in low lands. Association maize-cowpea, rice-maize and plantain-food crops. Control of animal digression, pests and diseases.

column4: Between the lowlands and the mountains of seven districts (Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing) and cover 15% of the country (545,500 ha). The plateaus are interrupted by mountain spurs and river valleys.
column5: Summer crops: maize, sorghum, beans, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Earlier planting than lowlands. Mixed farming (crops and livestock). Intensive and commercial farming follows that of lowlands. Gravity fed and sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is a small strip of land of the seven districts, Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing comprising 12% of the land area on the western part of country boarding the eastern Free State Province of the Republic of South Af
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is an extension of the lowlands in the south eastern part of the country, Quthing to Qachas Nek along the Senqu River and its tributary valleys covering 8% of the land area and even parts of Thaba-Tseka have similar conditions.
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation. Sorghum thrives well in this zone due to its better drought tolerance than maize.

column4: S. Nicolau (Fajã, Rª das Pratas-Fragata, Rª Brava, Caleijão, Queimadas, Juncalinho, Água das Patas)S. Antão: Porto Novo (Rª da Cruz, Alto Mira, Martiene, Lagedos, Rª Fria, Rª dos Bodes, Casa de Meio) - Sud et Ouest; Fogo: S. Filipe (Achada Malva, Patim, F
column5: Rainfed cultivation in maize and common beans. Pluvial land (35 ha) converted to irrigated areas (Faja Galery). Irrigated crops on wind-protected valleys with micro-climate that is favourable for sugar cane and fruit production. Fruits (mango) on the sides of the valleys with complementary irrigation. High water deficit in some zones according to season. Gravitational irrigation with water from streams and wells. Moderate micro-climate in hot humid season (July - Oct.) conducive for fruit and vegetable production (potato, cabbage, sweetpotato, citrus and mango). Little or no pests with the exception of millipedes. Insufficient rainfall. Irrigation of small farms with water bored more than 100 m deep on slopes. Water pumping from the sea level with several intermediate stations. Potential for roots and tuber production, pineapple, pawpaw and horticultural crops with micro-irrigation. Very high price of water.

column3: Low-Medium Altitude Semi-Arid and Sub-Humid Zones
column4: Santiago: Praia (Rªs de Cidade Velha, S. Martinho Grande e Pequeno); S. Domingos (Rª de Baía, Rª de Acahada Baleia, Monte Negro, Lagoa); Santa Cruz (Rª Seca, Rª da Picos, Rª de Santa Cruz); Santa Catarina (Rª Flamengos, Rª do Charco, Rª da Barca, Rª Boa E
column5: Irrigated zone especially in the valleys and on terrace slopes. Irrigation from water sources, wells and borings. In the recent years, fruit production has been market-driven with modernization of the irrigation system with drippers.

column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Rainfed cultivation on burnt land is practiced after a short fallow. Intensive cultivation of vegetables and potato in pluvial and under irrigation in dry season. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column4: Between the lowlands and the mountains of seven districts (Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing) and cover 15% of the country (545,500 ha). The plateaus are interrupted by mountain spurs and river valleys.
column5: Summer crops: maize, sorghum, beans, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Earlier planting than lowlands. Mixed farming (crops and livestock). Intensive and commercial farming follows that of lowlands. Gravity fed and sprinkler irrigation.

column4: Between the lowlands and the mountains of seven districts (Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing) and cover 15% of the country (545,500 ha). The plateaus are interrupted by mountain spurs and river valleys.

column4: It is a small strip of land of the seven districts, Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing comprising 12% of the land area on the western part of country boarding the eastern Free State Province of the Republic of South Af
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is an extension of the lowlands in the south eastern part of the country, Quthing to Qachas Nek along the Senqu River and its tributary valleys covering 8% of the land area and even parts of Thaba-Tseka have similar conditions.
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation. Sorghum thrives well in this zone due to its better drought tolerance than maize.

column5: Arabica coffee, tea, wheat, rice, potato, maize, cassava, fruit trees, vegetable crops, Drainage problems in valleys.

column4: Comprises the  wilayas (Regions) of Tiris Zemmour, Adrar, Inchiri and Tagant, the Moughataa of Boumdeïd (Assaba), Tamchakett (Hodh El Gharbi) and Oulata (Hodh Echarghui)
column5: Oasis-type agriculture: date palm dominated with sub stages of fruit trees, cereals (wheat, oat), vegetables (carrot, tomato, cabbage and forage (alfalfa). Sometimes recessional crops are found around oases and behind dams on limono sandy soils.

column4: Comprises the south of 4 wilayas (Regions): Trarza (the Moughataa of Boghé, Bababé and M'Bagne),  Gorgol (the Moughataa of Kaédi and Maghama),  Guidimakha (the Moughataa of Sélibaby)
column5: Agriculture: dominant. Rainfed and subsidence crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, watermelon, etc). Irrigated crops: rice, maize, sorghum, vegetables, fruit trees. Cultural techniques: dominated by manual practices. Riziculture: manual in Upper River (Brakna, Gorgol, Guidimakha), semi mechanized in lower River (Trarza for land preparation and harvesting). Use of herbicides: frequent.

column4: Comprises 3 wilayas (Regions): Assaba, 2 Hodhs without Moughataa (Divisions), Ould Yengé (Guidimakha), Mbout and Monguel (Gorgol), Aleg and Magta-Lahjar (Brakna), Mederdra and R'Kiz (Trarza).
column5: Rainfed crops and crops grown under dam (sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea). Mixed cropping is common and fertilizer use is rare. Use of animal traction: rare. Use of manure: frequent. Cultural operations: manual. Crop protection: seed treatments with fungicides. Use of improved varieties: rare. Vegetable cropping: developed by women cooperatives.

column5: Major vegetables crops grown are onion, Brinjal, creepers, tomato, chillies. Sugar cane plantation are mostly found in the marginal lands which are being abondoned in the actual context. Most of the irrigation projects are found in these regions, plots of state land are being parcelled into settlements  of defined size and leased to Agricultural Cooperatives. The irrigation system used are mainly overhead sprinkler. Pineapple has been cultivated in particular regions over large extent.

column4: Comprises the Region of Dakar, and the Atlantic coast of the Regions of Thiès, Louga and Saint-Louis.
column5: About 80% of the horticultural production of the country is provided by this zone, only about 7% of the land is irrigated. There is intensive rearing (bovine and poultry). However, pressure on water resources and land combined with low rainfall leads to progressive land salinity and sandiness following vegetation degradation and progressive dune threats.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column4: Woleu Ntem province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: Population density is not very high in the Woleu N'tem zone, and there is no problem with land availability. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 8 to 12 years. As in the Estuary province, pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column4: Konkouré, Wouré Kaba, Soya, Boulywel, Tolo, Timbo, Saramoussaya, Poredaka, Bouriya, Gongorè, Gnagara, Kegneko (Mamou); Koba, Mity, Ditinn, Boyé, Kanka Labé, Kebaly (Dalaba); Brouwal Tapè, Bantignèl, Massi, Sangaréah, Leymirou, Dongöl Touma, Ningué Landè,
column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Rainfed cultivation on burnt land is practiced after a short fallow. Intensive cultivation of vegetables and potato in pluvial and under irrigation in dry season. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column4: It is a small strip of land of the seven districts, Botha-Bothe, Leribe, Berea, Maseru, Mafeteng, Mohales Hoek and Quthing comprising 12% of the land area on the western part of country boarding the eastern Free State Province of the Republic of South Af
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation.

column4: It is an extension of the lowlands in the south eastern part of the country, Quthing to Qachas Nek along the Senqu River and its tributary valleys covering 8% of the land area and even parts of Thaba-Tseka have similar conditions.
column5: Crops (summer and winter), fodder crops. Mixed farming, intensive and commercial more than in other zones. Summer crops: maize, sorghum, potatoes, sunflower. Winter: wheat, peas. Pumped sprinkler irrigation. Sorghum thrives well in this zone due to its better drought tolerance than maize.

column4: The zone lies on the eastern part of the country and borders with Kwazulu Natal of the Republic of South Africa on the East. It covers the largest part of the country, 65% (1.6 million) of the total area, but has the smallest extension of arable land. The
column5: Crops (all). More extensive livestock farming than crop production. Gravity fed irrigation. Shortest growing season.

column4: Comprises the  wilayas (Regions) of Tiris Zemmour, Adrar, Inchiri and Tagant, the Moughataa of Boumdeïd (Assaba), Tamchakett (Hodh El Gharbi) and Oulata (Hodh Echarghui)
column5: Oasis-type agriculture: date palm dominated with sub stages of fruit trees, cereals (wheat, oat), vegetables (carrot, tomato, cabbage and forage (alfalfa). Sometimes recessional crops are found around oases and behind dams on limono sandy soils.

column4: Comprises the south of 4 wilayas (Regions): Trarza (the Moughataa of Boghé, Bababé and M'Bagne),  Gorgol (the Moughataa of Kaédi and Maghama),  Guidimakha (the Moughataa of Sélibaby)
column5: Agriculture: dominant. Rainfed and subsidence crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, watermelon, etc). Irrigated crops: rice, maize, sorghum, vegetables, fruit trees. Cultural techniques: dominated by manual practices. Riziculture: manual in Upper River (Brakna, Gorgol, Guidimakha), semi mechanized in lower River (Trarza for land preparation and harvesting). Use of herbicides: frequent.

column4: Diffa Region: South Diffa and South Maïné Soroa Divisions; Zinder Region: Matamèye, Magaria, South Gouré and Mirriah Centre and South Divisions. Maradi Region: Tessaoua, Aguié, Guidan Roumdji, Madarounfa, South Mayahi, Sud Dakoro; Divisions; Tahoua Region
column5: Rainfed crops: cereals (millet, sorghum, rice) legumes (cowpea), off-season crops: vegetables and fruit trees.

column4: Comprises far north parts of the Dagana, Podor, Matam and Bakel administrative Divisions.
column5: Rice cultivation, irrigated vegetable production and subsidence cropping are practiced in the Walo (zone closed to water sources). The main subsidence crops are sorghum and maize that are grown on flood lands of the Walo, after the withdrawal of river waters following the annual rise in the water level occurring in rainy season. Rainfed crops such as millet, groundnut, tropical-type vegetables, etc. are cultivated Diéri. There is artisan fishing in rivers, lake Guiers and their different branching as well as the extensive livestock in Diéri. The development of rice cultivation and intensive deforestation have led to problems of chemical degradation of waters, wind and water erosion as well as salinization and alkalinization of soils in this zone.

column4: Comprises Kolda and Ziguinchor administrative Regions.
column5: This zone is very favourable for agricultural activities because of its precipitation, and the migrants from Arachidier basin and even east Senegal come in for agricultural purposes. The main activities are upland rice and cotton cultivation, traditional fishing in rivers and extensive livestock activities.

column4: Comprises Fatick, Kaolack and Diourbel regions, Mbour Division and an important part of Thiès, Tivaouane, Kébémer and Louga Divisions.
column5: As noted from its name, this zone is dominated by groundnut cultivation, in alternation with rainfed millet (les than 1% of the land is irrigated). Agricultural practices are characterized by the disappearance of fallows due to the high human pressure on land and the absence of policy to maintain soil fertility. This explains the multiple factors of land deterioration, amplified by extensive livestock activities that consume the few plants found and protected areas dominated by species of Combretaceae and Mimosaceae (mostly Faidherbia albida).

column4: Comprises Fatick, Kaolack and Diourbel regions, Mbour Division and an important part of Thiès, Tivaouane, Kébémer and Louga Divisions.

column4: Comprises Bakel Division and Tambacounda administrative Region. The lowest population density of Senegal is found here (8 inhabitants/km2).
column5: Agricultural activities are variable. The low population density in this zone has enabled movements of people from other populated zones for extensive agriculture purposes and transhumant animal rearing with its associated problems on grazing. Inland fishing is also practiced in rivers Falémé, Gambia and Niokolo. Lumbering is carried out in unclassified domain, with yearly quotas of 500 000 quintals of coal and 60 000 m3 of wood. The presence of Niokolo-Koba national park and important animal reserves are favourable for the tourism. The zone has potential for mining. The exploitation of the mining resources shall include environmental risks, that add to the existing problems such as bush fires, overgrazing, deforestation and water erosion.

column5: Cereal based, enset based and shifting cultivation are common agricultural practices in the zone. In some parts of the zone nomadic pastoralism of agricultural practices are also exercised.

column4: Estuary province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: population density is very high in the Estuary zone (50-60 % of national population), pressure on land is high and this reduces the fallow period. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 5 to 7 years. Pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column3: Oyem, Bitam, Minvoul, Mitzic and Médouneu
column4: Woleu Ntem province
column5: Conventional market gardening. The methods used are more modern with applications of fertilizers, chemical pesticides and irrigation for farmers with large farms. There is no mastery of appropriate cultural techniques in the applications of these technologies. Crop rotation is practiced in some zones, while in others, pure cropping is practice. Food crops: Population density is not very high in the Woleu N'tem zone, and there is no problem with land availability. Food crop are generally cultivated on burnt land after a fallow of 8 to 12 years. As in the Estuary province, pests and diseases are not controlled by any recommended method. Farmers do not control plant parasites except in situation of severe infestations that they request assistance form competent bodies.

column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Rainfed cultivation on burnt land is practiced after a short fallow. Intensive cultivation of vegetables and potato in pluvial and under irrigation in dry season. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column5: Cereal based, enset based and shifting cultivation are the common agricultural practices along with animal rearing.

column5: Pluvial agriculture (millet, maize, sorghum, cowpeas, tubers), cash crops (cotton) and irrigated crops (rice, vegetable crops) as well as sedentary livestock comprised mainly of small ruminants and bovines.

column4: The zone covers the provinces of Gourman, Gnagnan, Tapoa, Kompienga and Komandjari.
column5: Extensive rainfed agriculture (millet, maize, sorghum, groundnut, cowpea, cotton...) and irrigated agriculture (rice, vegetables) and extensive livestock rearing (bovine, small ruminant and poultry).

column4: Benty, Farmoriah, Kabak, Kakossa, Moussaya, Sikhourou, Kaliya (Forécariah); Wonkifon, Maneah, Kouria (Coyah); Conakry; Khorira, Wassou, Tanènè, Tondon, Baadi (Dubreka); Koba, Tamita, Lisso, Kolia, Doupourou, Tougnifily, Mankounta (Boffa); Kamsar, Kanfaran
column5: Rainfed cultures in plains, lowland and slash and burn agriculture. Irrigation of non seasonal crops, rotations of rice/vegetable crops/maize; rice/groundnut/cassava. Fight against crabs and other predators, saline rising in mangrove plain. Fight against weeds, treatment against insects and diseases.

column4: Kalinko, Selouma, Lansanya, Gnagnakaly, Datifèrè, M'bonè (Dinguiraye); Dogomè, Alpha Moussaya, Kankama, Dialakoro, Bissikirima, Banko, Konidou, N'dèma, Kindoyé (Dabola); Marela, Snadeniya, Passaya, Heremakono, Niala, Tiro, Sangoya, Bagnan, Kobikoro, Bèndo
column5: Rainfed cropping in plains and on burnt land. Irrigation of the crops at off-season from October; rotation rice/cotton/cassava/fonio or cotton/groundnut/maize in hills; rice/vegetables in plains. Control of animal damage, weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Konkouré, Wouré Kaba, Soya, Boulywel, Tolo, Timbo, Saramoussaya, Poredaka, Bouriya, Gongorè, Gnagara, Kegneko (Mamou); Koba, Mity, Ditinn, Boyé, Kanka Labé, Kebaly (Dalaba); Brouwal Tapè, Bantignèl, Massi, Sangaréah, Leymirou, Dongöl Touma, Ningué Landè,
column5: The agrarian system combines very intensive cropping zones in the tapades and the extensive zones in the periphery. Animal rearing is associated with agriculture. Rainfed cultivation on burnt land is practiced after a short fallow. Intensive cultivation of vegetables and potato in pluvial and under irrigation in dry season. Mixed cropping of cassava, taro, sweetpotato, gourd and vegetables in the tapades. Control of animal digression, weeds, pests and diseases is common.

column4: Oran-Mostaganem
column5: Irrigated or rainfed vegetable cultivation. Rainfed cereal cultivation. Biennial rotation (cereals-fodder or cereals-potato)

column5: Rainfed cropping in plains, lowlands and forest lands (burnt land). Mixture of crops of the Sudan and the Guinea forest zones. Irrigation at off-seasons from December (West preforest zone) and November (preforest zone). Rotation rice-groundnut-cassava in small hill and rice-vegetables-maize in low lands. Association maize-cowpea, rice-maize and plantain-food crops. Control of animal digression, pests and diseases.

column4: Comprises the south of 4 wilayas (Regions): Trarza (the Moughataa of Boghé, Bababé and M'Bagne),  Gorgol (the Moughataa of Kaédi and Maghama),  Guidimakha (the Moughataa of Sélibaby)
column5: Agriculture: dominant. Rainfed and subsidence crops: sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, watermelon, etc). Irrigated crops: rice, maize, sorghum, vegetables, fruit trees. Cultural techniques: dominated by manual practices. Riziculture: manual in Upper River (Brakna, Gorgol, Guidimakha), semi mechanized in lower River (Trarza for land preparation and harvesting). Use of herbicides: frequent.

column4: Comprises 3 wilayas (Regions): Assaba, 2 Hodhs without Moughataa (Divisions), Ould Yengé (Guidimakha), Mbout and Monguel (Gorgol), Aleg and Magta-Lahjar (Brakna), Mederdra and R'Kiz (Trarza).
column5: Rainfed crops and crops grown under dam (sorghum, millet, maize, cowpea). Mixed cropping is common and fertilizer use is rare. Use of animal traction: rare. Use of manure: frequent. Cultural operations: manual. Crop protection: seed treatments with fungicides. Use of improved varieties: rare. Vegetable cropping: developed by women cooperatives.

column4: Covers the majority of the national territory, between 5° and 9° N and the towns of Bouar (Nana Mambéré), Bossembélé (Ombella M'Poko), Bozoum (Ouham Péndé), Bossangoa (Ouham), Kaga Bandoro (Nana Gribizi), Sibut (Kémo), Bambari (Ouaka), Ndélé south, Bria (
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In some areas the density of trees and shrubs limits deep ploughing. Animal traction is used in the savannah and cotton zones for ploughing and transportation. The cropping calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not used in food crop cultivation. The soil is placed on fallow for more than 4 years.

column4: Covers from West to East the town of Paoua (Ouham Péndé), Batangafo (Ouham), Ndélé (Bamingui Bangoran) and Ouadda (Haute-Kotto)
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. In the cotton areas, some farmers use animal traction, but the rest of the system is manual. The cultural calendar depends on rainfall regime. Fertilizers are not applied on food crops. The soil is placed on fallow for a long period for natural regeneration.

column4: Covers southern towns and along River Oubangui. The towns concerned are: Nola (Sangha Mbaéré), Berberati (Mambéré Kadeï), Mbaïki (Lobaye), Bangui (Ombella M'Poko), Mobaye (Basse-Kotto) and Bangassou (Mbomou).
column5: Fallowing is practised with bush burning. The high density of trees limits deep ploughing.

column5: Rainfed cropping on forest land (burnt land), in plains and in low lands; high soil occupation; irrigation from starts December for 3 to 4 months only. Short dry season. Rotation rice, groundnut, maize, cassava in small hills and rice, vegetables in low lands; mixed cropping groundnut-maize, maize-cowpea, rice-maize, plantain-food crops and plantain-fruit crops. Control of weeds, pests and diseases.

column4: Nyanza province (Siaya, Kisumu), Western province (Kakamega, Busia, Bungoma), Nandi, Narok.
column5: Sugarcane farming marginal, maize farming.

column5: Direct planting, transplanting and propagate vegetatively some fruit crops, broadcasting and drilling field crops. Wheat and Faba been cultivated by the floods in Hud es-Sileim.
